Mallinckrodt Inc. operates a facility located at Mallinckrodt and 2nd St. in St. Louis, MO.  The facility manufactures product for the pharmaceutical industries.

The Mallinckrodt Inc. -St. Louis Plant operates under the Federal Process Safety Management Regulation (OSHA PSM) and Clean Air Act Risk Management Program (EPA-RMP).


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

It is Mallinckrodt's objective to provide a safe and healthful work environment through the prevention of occupational injuries and illnesses, and preventing offsite impacts to public receptors and the environment.  Mallinckrodt will develop, manufacture, use, distribute, and dispose of chemical products safely and in a manner that ensures protection of health and the environment.  The company is committed to providing the necessary information and support to employees, customers, distributors, contractors, and the general public so that the same, high standard of care is applied in the handling of our products throughout their life cycle.

This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:
-A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation.
-A summary of results from our assessment of the potential off-site consequences from accidental chemical release.
-An overview of our accidental release prevention program.
-An overview of our emergency response plan.
-An overview of planned improvements at the plant to help prevent accidental chemical releases form occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public and the environment.
-The certification required by EPA's RMP rule.
-The detailed information or data elements about the Mallinckrodt risk management program.  


FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Mallinckrodt manufactures inorganic salts, pharmaceuticals, contrast media imaging agents and peptides.  The facility is located on a 40-acre par

cel in St. Louis, MO and is comprised of about 50 buildings containing manufacturing operations, research and development, utility services, and warehousing.

The EPA-regulated substances are chlorine and chloroform. Chlorine is utilized to manufacture the contract media agents.  Chlorine is staged and then delivered one cylinder at a time for usage in a reaction to manufacture the contrast media. Chloroform is stored in 55-gallon drums in the Building 76 warehouse and outside the B235 process area. Chloroform is used to manufacture pharmaceutical products in Building 235.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Mallinckrodt handles thousands of pounds of chlorine and chloroform each year.  There have been no incidents which have involved deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on or off-site, and there are no instances of adverse impact to the employees, community, or the environment in the past five years.


THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Mallinckrodt has a robust emergency response program that includes administrative and operational response procedures, training, and drills.  The program meets the requirements of OSHA and EPA for protection of the safety of our employees and the community and provides for the protection of the environment.    Our emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  This program includes interface with the LEPC and St. Louis St. Fire Department and has been audited by state and federal agencies many times.  Mallinckrodt works closely with the local response organizations, has included representatives as drill observers, and supports responder training through the loan of equipment and facilities for training purposes.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Mallinckrodt uses a variety of means to prevent accidental releases.  These include written procedures and training, preventive maintenance, change management and

permitting procedures, incident investigations, inspections, audits and drills.  Furthermore, there are many engineering controls in place that include, automatic shutdown systems, pressure relief systems, spill containment, and water and foam vapor suppression systems that provide multiple layers of protection. Active process safety engineering practices, various internal leadership teams and audits by corporate, local, state, and federal agencies further insure an environment of continuous improvement and incremental risk reduction.
